nodes.bodyText: There seems to be no usage for this method.
thanks for pointing it out, will remove. a relic from an earlier version of my patch.
Do we need to worry about this assumption not being true in clusters already deployed?

because clusters are not already deployed, if we introduce this change now, we do not have that problem. Of course we are referring to customer deployments here and not any internal test setups, right?
Yes, agreed.
I believe this can be moved up to after the "verifyFilesInPath" call. Also, should we repeat the check for presence of intermediate directory path in keyTable in getMissingParents() again?

will move the code snippet as suggested.
would there be any benefit checking for the presence of intermediate directory in keyTable again? the objective of the function, as the name suggests is focussed on getting parents in the path which are missing.
I think we can combine the two functions to avoid doing DB reads twice. We could probably change OMDirectoryResult structure to include the result + missing dirs.
Yes, @hanishakoneru's suggestion makes sense if we want to avoid doing the same reads twice.
Thanks, makes sense. Will make the suggested change.

How are we calculating the objectID here? Is this to ensure that the objectIDs are unique?
I am not sure what the effects would be as we set the transactionID as the objectID everywhere else.

the base object ID for every create is the transaction log index left shifted by 8 bits (tx log index << 8). OMFileRequest.getObjIdFromTxId() implements this logic. I have replaced all 3 places in the code where a object id is generated, with this call. intermediate directories are created iteratively by doing a +1 starting from the base object ID. that will guarantee each object id is unique - given that the base object id starts with the unique transaction log index.
I will put in asserts to ensure there is no overflow.

We could still end up with the same objectID for keys and buckets/ volumes.
For example, Lets say Trxn 1 creates dir1/dir2/dir3. So objectID for dir1 would be 1 << 8 + 1 i.e. 257.
Now let's say Trxn 257 comes in and creates bucket1. Then, dir1 and bucket1 would have the same objectID.
Let's change the objectID for volumes, buckets and prefixInfo's too.
sure, will use the same object id scheme for volume and bucket.
Let's not set the updateID here as it will be set later.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -228,10 +289,8 @@ private OmKeyInfo createDirectoryKeyInfo(OzoneManager ozoneManager,
         .setReplicationType(HddsProtos.ReplicationType.RATIS)
         .setReplicationFactor(HddsProtos.ReplicationFactor.ONE)
         .setFileEncryptionInfo(encryptionInfo.orNull())
-        .setAcls(OzoneAclUtil.fromProtobuf(keyArgs.getAclsList()))
-        .setObjectID(transactionLogIndex)
-        .setUpdateID(transactionLogIndex)
-        .build();
+        .setObjectID(objectId)
+        .setUpdateID(0);

nodes.bodyText: sure, will make the change. any specific reason why it might not be a good idea?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -228,10 +289,8 @@ private OmKeyInfo createDirectoryKeyInfo(OzoneManager ozoneManager,
         .setReplicationType(HddsProtos.ReplicationType.RATIS)
         .setReplicationFactor(HddsProtos.ReplicationFactor.ONE)
         .setFileEncryptionInfo(encryptionInfo.orNull())
-        .setAcls(OzoneAclUtil.fromProtobuf(keyArgs.getAclsList()))
-        .setObjectID(transactionLogIndex)
-        .setUpdateID(transactionLogIndex)
-        .build();
+        .setObjectID(objectId)
+        .setUpdateID(0);

nodes.bodyText:
No strong reason. Just to avoid setting it twice.
But this leads me to another thought. Instead of having a separate setObjectID and setUpdateID methods, we could have 1 method which updates both. This would ensure that we never miss setting the updateID when setting objectID. Just a thought.. unrelated to this Jira.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -228,10 +289,8 @@ private OmKeyInfo createDirectoryKeyInfo(OzoneManager ozoneManager,
         .setReplicationType(HddsProtos.ReplicationType.RATIS)
         .setReplicationFactor(HddsProtos.ReplicationFactor.ONE)
         .setFileEncryptionInfo(encryptionInfo.orNull())
-        .setAcls(OzoneAclUtil.fromProtobuf(keyArgs.getAclsList()))
-        .setObjectID(transactionLogIndex)
-        .setUpdateID(transactionLogIndex)
-        .build();
+        .setObjectID(objectId)
+        .setUpdateID(0);

nodes.bodyText: We can avoid passing the createPrefix param and use parentKeyInfos != null check only instead.

the createPrefix represents a configuration parameter. whereas parentKeyInfos can actually be null.
yes, things will work as you suggested. I can remove the createPrefix argument. But given that it represents a config control, I would wish to retain it.
If you insist, then I will go ahead and remove it.
Sure. I am ok with keeping the createPrefix param.
We already computed getObjIdRangeFromTxId() in the calling function while computing baseObjId (line 180). Can we avoid calling it again here?

the code around the previous call doesn't need to bother about the object range, only the base id. the code here requires the object range.
worry about an extra call during directory create might be premature in the overall cpu profile?
No I was just thinking from code cleaning perspective.
We can move this inside the second if else condition.
ok
Can we update this debug log message to indicate that the missing parent directory is being created/ added to KeyTable?
ok
We use this function multiple times (more than getObjIdRangeFromTxId()). Wouldn't it be better to directly execute shift operation here instead of calling getObjIdRangeFromTxId()?
ok
Double check of status.isDirectory()
will remove
This case would never be reached in this test suit as createPrefix config is true by default and we are not overriding it.
I'll fix that in a subsequent patch. this is a comment from @mukul1987 as well. we will include both cases in the parametrised test.
